content:
By Hamish Hastie
April 8, 2019 — 2.26pm

It’s dinnertime, the kids are sick, runny-nosed and screaming at the top of their lungs.

They need to see a doctor tomorrow but it's after hours, and there is small hope of hearing anyone on the other end of the phone, with that racket going on in the background.

More than two million GP appointments are booked each week in Australia, according to the Royal Australian College of GPs, and situations such as the one above are turning patients and parents to the internet in droves to get the bookings done.

Despite reports of tampering with patient reviews, and concerns over how it used patient data, the nation’s biggest online GP booking site Healthengine revealed more than 9 million appointments were booked in 2018 – a 35 per cent increase compared to 2017.

Advertisement

Nationally, 60 per cent of appointments booked on Healthengine were being made outside working hours.

One in five users were seeing their GP within four hours of booking their appointment and 55 per cent were seeing them within 24 hours.

Healthengine was founded in Perth and WA patients are its biggest users – of the 9 million appointments, 2.3 million were booked in WA.

This was a 28 per cent increase on 2017 and represented 800,000 patients, meaning almost a third of the state's total population is now booking online.

One of them is Perth's Louise Pedreschi, mother to two children under five.

She wasn’t surprised at the figures, saying she used the internet to book all her appointments, preferring the after-hours convenience.

“I can pick the exact doctor and time that best suits,” she said.

“Also I like the fact I don’t have to stop what I’m doing to make an appointment.

“If I was to call I’m put on hold and rather than taking two minutes to do it, it then becomes a five to 10-minute job depending on the wait.”

Ms Pedreschi said just because she used the internet to book her appointments didn't mean she couldn't have a good rapport with a doctor.

“We have a family doctor who sees all four of us and it’s a great relationship,” she said.

“That’s why I like to book on the app, to make sure Dr Jas is free when we need to go.”

Despite the jump in online bookings, millions of Australians still book their GP appointments the old-fashioned way.

Radio 6PR presenter and Gen X-er Simon Beaumont uses the internet to look at real estate and book accommodation, but for managing his health, he picks up the phone.

“I call my doctor's rooms because having been a long-term customer, I can always get an appointment,” he said.

“Doctor Gary has helped me for nearly 10 years with various medical concerns, and he is especially good at helping me manage interrelated health issues.

“He has my family, social and medical history, which I would imagine My Health or Healthengine would not know or have access to.

“He knows my health ‘on and off the paddock’, to use a football phrase. Most importantly I trust him and his interpretations.”

Australian Medical Association WA President Omar Khorshid said online booking engines were 'the future'.

“Internet-based tools such as online booking services have been a growth area for some years now and offer a very convenient method of finding a GP and checking what times they are available,” he said.

“It is important, however, that information provided by patients is kept confidential and not shared with or sold to third parties."

Healthengine chief executive and co-founder Marcus Tan said digital health bookings could help ease pressures on the health system and prevent the 3 million avoidable emergency department presentations every year.

Loading

“By making healthcare experiences easy and accessible, technology can, and clearly is, improving outcomes for both the patient and Australia’s health system,” he said.

“Technology can facilitate a connection between patients and practices when they need it the most to alleviate this pressure on emergency resources.

"The opportunity is glaringly obvious. As Australians are rapidly realising the benefits of a digital health system we must continue to support patients in understanding how to embrace digital health in a safe, secure way to support a more efficient and productive care system."

Hamish Hastie is WAtoday's business reporter.

title: Drop the phone: Millions turn to the internet to book GP appointments
